title: Buddha Bowl
description: Move over açaí bowls, the savoury breakfast bowl is the new player in town and it has more nutrients than you could shake an açaí berry at!
ingredients:
2 eggs
Dash of apple cider vinegar
2 pre-cooked paleo sausages
1 cup cauliflower ‘rice’ (see recipe)
1 avocado, sliced
¼ cucumber, sliced
2 handfuls leafy greens

Optional garnishes: fresh herbs, sliced chilli, sliced spring onions, lemon wedge, salt and pepper to taste, sauerkraut or kimchi (see recipe!)
method:
1. Bring a small pot of water to boil on a medium heat and add a dash of apple cider vinegar.
2. Heat a small drizzle of oil in a fry-pan on medium heat. Add the cauliflower rice to the pan and cook for 4-5 minutes, stirring, until browned and warmed through. Reserve pan.
4. Place leafy greens and cooked cauliflower rice into a serving bowl and set aside.
5. Add the sausages to the same fry-pan and cook for a few minutes to reheat them until they’re hot through.
6. Meanwhile, gently crack the eggs into the pot of boiling water and poach for about 1-2 minutes, or until cooked to your liking. Once cooked, remove eggs with a slotted spoon and pop them onto a plate lined with a paper towel to drain any excess water.  
7. Add cooked sausage and eggs to the serving bowl and top with avocado and cucumber. Sprinkle over any garnishes you desire and enjoy!
tips:
Top tip: Feel free to change up the ingredients! Instead of sausage, choose salmon (smoked or fresh), mackerel, or bacon. Or throw in some of last night’s chilli con carne (see recipe!), and make it complete with spinach, avocado and a poached egg. The options are endless! Just double everything to make this a serves 2 recipe!

Top tip: We love mixing 1 tsp of speedy mayo (see recipe!) with 1 Tbsp lemon juice for a tasty drizzle for this bowl!
tags: Breakfast, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Insulin Friendly, Nut Free,

title: Chocolate Thickshake
ingredients:
• 1 cup cubed frozen zucchini or cauliflower 
  • 40g of protein from protein powder (for me that’s 4 scoops of NuZest Clean Lean Protein), or 4 scoops of Vital Peptides collagen powder if you don’t want it sweetened, but remember that cocoa is quite bitter. 
  • 1 tbsp dark unsweetened cocoa powder
  • ½-1 cup water or nut milk (depending on how thick you want your shake to be)
method:
1. Put all ingredients into a blender or food processor and blend until smooth.

You can also make this into a smoothie bowl by adding less water to make the texture thicker and then topping with any combination of the following ingredients: 

  • Berries: blueberries, strawberries, raspberries, cranberries
  • nuts: macadamia nuts, almonds, walnuts, pili nuts, pecans
  • cocao nibs
  • coconut: shredded / flaked / coconut chips
  • chia seeds / hemp seed / sesame seeds / pumpkin seeds
  • nut or seed butters: peanut butter, almond butter, pecan butter, cashew butter
tips:
Frozen zucchini or cauliflower is the surprising winner in this recipe. Not only does it make the shake cold and deliciously thick, it also adds a serve of vegetables and fibre into my morning to get those bowels moving! The protein powder helps to keep my blood sugar stable and the cocoa is a good source of antioxidants.

 

You can prepare your frozen courgette the night before. Cut the courgette into 1cm cubes and then blanch in boiling water for one minute (this isn’t essential, but makes the shake smoother). Store in the freezer in a glass dish or bag. Forgotten to freeze your courgette? Just use cubed fresh courgette and some ice cubes.
tags: Breakfast, Snack, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Insulin Friendly

title: Raspberry Coconut Chia Porridge
description: For all of you porridge lovers!
ingredients:
• ¼ cup chia seeds
  • 150ml coconut milk
  • 1-2 serves of protein powder (to hit 40-50g - will vary based on the protein you use). 
  • Zest of 1 orange
  • 1 tsp cinnamon (optional)
  • ½ cup of berries (fresh or frozen)
  • Optional toppings: 1 tbsp flaked coconut, ½ grated apple, 1 tbsp chopped nuts or seeds, nut butter
method:
1. Put the milk, chia seeds, cinnamon, collagen or protein powder, orange zest and berries into a mason jar or bowl. Stir with a spoon to combine.
  2. Cover securely with a lid or plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight. If you’re in a rush then 20 minutes is enough time for the seeds to absorb the milk.

  3. Remove from the fridge and add your toppings. You can also add more milk if you want a creamier texture or blend it to make it smoother.
tags: breakfast, snacks, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Insulin Friendly

title: Avocado and Egg Boats
description: Although slightly fiddly, we can confirm these are well worth the effort! Note ** if you’re not a fan of hot avocado, this one probably isn’t for you!
ingredients:
2 ripe avocados
4 eggs
Crushed red pepper flakes
Salt and pepper
Finely chopped chives, green onions or herbs (optional)
Avocado oil
method:
1. Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F).
2. Cut avocados in half and remove stones. Using a tablespoon, remove enough flesh from the center of each avocado half to allow an egg to fit snugly in there.
3. Place the avocado halves (in skin) in a baking dish - you want them to fit tightly in there so that they don’t collapse whilst cooking. Sprinkle some crushed red pepper flakes into each half.
4. Crack the eggs into a bowl. Using a spoon, transfer one yolk into each avocado half, then carefully spoon in as much egg white as you can without it spilling out.  
5. Season with salt and pepper, then bake for 15-20 minutes, until the egg whites are set and the yolks are no longer runny. If the avocado start to brown then cover lightly with foil.  
6. Remove from the oven and garnish with chives/green onions/herbs and a drizzle of avocado oil.
7. Serve with a protein source such as salmon (as one egg only provides around 7g of protein) and a side of sauerkraut.
tips: Top tip: Scramble any leftover egg white with another egg and some smoked salmon to reach your protein target.
tags: Breakfast, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Soy Free, Insulin Friendly, Nut Free

title: Hot Pro-Chia Porridge
description: The Pro-Chia (Protein Chia) is a great, higher protein breakfastoption if you’re missing your warm cinnamon-y porridge in thewinter months.
ingredients:
¼ cup chia seeds
150mL unsweetened nut milk (e.g. almond, coconut)
30g vanilla protein powder
1 tsp ground cinnamon
1 tsp vanilla extract

To Serve:
½ cup frozen raspberries, defrosted
1 Tbsp unsweetened, toasted coconut flakes (optional)
1 Tbsp sliced almonds (optional)
method:
1. Soak chia seeds in milk in a mason jar or bowl, covered, overnight in the refrigerator.
2. When ready to eat, add the chia mixture to a saucepan with the protein powder, cinnamon and vanilla extract and heat until warmed through. You can also blitz in a blender before heating if you want a smoother texture.
3. Serving suggestions: top with berries, toasted coconut and sliced almonds.
tips: Top tips: You can prepare this ahead of time and store it in the fridge for up to 5 days, then simply heat it up when you want to eat it. You add in the berries when heating to give the whole porridge a berry flavor.
tags: Breakfast, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Insulin Friendly

title: Bounty Bars
ingredients:
For the coconut filling:

  • 240ml coconut milk
  • ½ -1 tsp Monk fruit sweetener (you can also use Stevia however it has a slightly bitter after taste).  Test the sweetness and how sweet you want it. 
  • 3 tbsp coconut oil
  • 200g desiccated coconut
  • Pinch of sea salt

For the chocolate coating:

  • 1 block of Lindt 90% cocoa chocolate, melted
  • ½-1 tsp monk fruit extract if you like it a little sweeter.
method:
1. Make the coconut filling by combining the coconut milk, honey, and coconut oil in a medium-sized saucepan, stirring over low heat until combined. Add the desiccated coconut and stir to combine.
  2. Line a deep baking tray with greaseproof paper and press the coconut mixture into the pan so that it’s about 1.5cm thick. Place in the freezer until well set.
  3. Remove the coconut from the freezer, place on a chopping board and cut into chocolate bar-sized slices. 
  4. Carefully place the bars into the melted chocolate and turn to evenly cover.
  5. Place back in the freezer to set and remove just before eating.
tips:
Bounty bars are one of my favourite treats, so I was very keen to create a recipe that was low in sugar but still gave me that coconutty hit.

(Makes 5 bars)
tags: sweets, snacks, gluten free, dairy free, vegetarian, vegan, insulin friendly

title: Chocolate Brownies
ingredients:
• 150g 90% cocoa solids dark chocolate
  • 150g ghee
  • 3 eggs
  • 100g ground almonds
  • 2 tbsp honey
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 1 tsp vanilla extract
  • ½-1 tsp Himalayan pink salt
  • 200g fresh or frozen  raspberries
method:
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (350°F). Line a 20x20cm square baking tin (at least 2¼ inches deep) with greaseproof paper.
  2. Melt the chocolate and ghee together in a heatproof bowl suspended over a saucepan of simmering water.
  3. Beat the eggs, almonds, honey, cinnamon, vanilla, and salt together in a food processor or using a hand whisk until it forms a cake batter. Beat in the melted chocolate.
  4. Pour the mixture into the prepared tin and scatter with the raspberries.
  5. Bake for around 20 minutes or until cooked on the outside but still fudgy in the middle. Cool and cut into small squares.
tips:
These are incredibly delicious brownies - as good as they get. They probably won’t be as sweet as you’re used to but the point of this diet is to get your taste buds more used to savoury foods so even the little bit of sugar in these tastes sweet to you.

If you don’t have insulin resistance then you can probably increase the amount of honey to 4 tablespoons. For those that do have insulin resistance, remember that honey is still a sweetened which may raise your blood sugar, so these are a treat for a couple of times a month, not every day.

(Makes 16 brownies)
tags: Sweets, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Insulin Friendly

title: Coconut Chocolate Mousse
ingredients:
• 400ml can full fat coconut milk (refrigerated, preferably overnight, so that the coconut cream rises to the surface)
  • 100g 90% cocoa chocolate (or 100% if you’re brave!)
method:
1. Open the can of coconut milk and scoop the cream off the top into a glass bowl (be careful not to get too much of the watery liquid in there).
  2. Heat a saucepan of water until simmering and a place a glass bowl over the top so that it sits securely in place but is not touching the water. Break the chocolate into the bowl and stir until it’s fully melted.
  3. Whip the coconut cream with an electric beater (as you would with normal cream) then fold the melted chocolate through it. 
  4. Place the mousse in the refrigerator to firm up, then serve in small scoops with fresh berries (this is really rich, so you don’t need much!).
tips: This is a rather decadent recipe! While low in sugar, this is still an incredibly delicious mousse. It’s also really easy to make. When you’re choosing a coconut milk, have a look at the back of the tin and chose one with the least additives (and certainly no added sugar). The additives, while not great for us, also prevent the coconut cream from separating which is not something that we want for this recipe.
tags: Sweets, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Nut Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Insulin Friendly

title: Flaxseed Tortillas
ingredients:
• 75g (½ cup) flaxseeds
  • 4 eggs, beaten
  • ¼ tsp salt
method:
1. Grind the flaxseeds in a blender to make a fine flaxseed meal. Then add the eggs and salt and blend until the ingredients are well mixed. Leave the mixture for a few minutes to thicken.
  2. Add a little oil (just enough to very lightly coat it) to a frying pan over a medium heat.
  3. Pour enough mixture into the pan to make a thin layer, then cook until the edges start to separate from the side of the pan. Flip the tortilla and cook for another 30 seconds until lightly browned. 
  4. Remove the tortilla from the pan and repeat the process until you’ve made a stack of tortillas. The heat and moisture created by stacking them will help to make them more malleable. 
  5. Serve with your favourite Mexican food!
tips:
This is a great recipe to replace the glutinous tortillas so that you can still enjoy Mexican night. Fill these with your favourite Mexican foods or my favourite, Ceviche

Top tip: I used sunflower seeds as I didn’t have flaxseeds and it worked just as well, so don’t be afraid to experiment with different seeds.
tags: sides, condiments,	Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Soy Free, Insulin Friendly, Nut Free, Vegetarian

title: Quinoa Salad
ingredients:
• 180g quinoa
  • Filtered water
  • 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar

For the salad and dressing:

  • 200g cherry tomatoes
  • 2 spring onions, finely chopped
  • Bunch of fresh herbs (mint, basil and parsley is a good combination), chopped
  • 100g goat or sheep feta
  • 2 tbsp pomegranate molasses
  • 2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
  • Zest and juice of 1 lemon
  • Salt and pepper
method:
1. Put the quinoa, 250ml warm filtered water, and apple cider vinegar in a glass container. Cover and leave in a warm area for 12-24 hours. 
  2. Remove the lid and fill to the top with warm water. Stir and tilt the container to move the foam around. The foam contains the anti-nutrients and bitterness so needs to be removed: scoop off the foam and repeat the process (fill, stir,  tilt) until the water runs clear and the foaming stops. 
  3. Put the drained quinoa in a small saucepan with 250ml water. Cover and simmer gently for 12-15 minutes or until the quinoa has absorbed all of the water. 
  4. Meanwhile, chop the tomatoes into small cubes and place in a large bowl with the spring onion and herbs. Crumble the feta over the top. 
  5. Combine the molasses, oil, lemon juice and zest in a small jar. Season with salt and pepper and shake to combine.
  6. Once cooked, add the quinoa to the salad, drizzle in the dressing and toss to combine.
tips:
Quinoa is actually a seed, not a grain. Some people with an autoimmune condition (such as Hashimoto’s Thyroiditis, coeliac disease, or endometriosis) might not tolerate it as it contains saponins which can damage the gut lining (read more here), but most of us tolerate it well.

The secret to making it less inflammatory (and tasting less bitter too!) is to soak it for 12-24 hours prior to cooking with it. While this might sound like a lot of work, it’s actually really simple:
tags: Lunch, Dinner, Side, Gluten free, Vegetarian, Nut Free, Egg Free, Soy Free

title: Cauliflower Rice
ingredients:
• 1 head of cauliflower
  • 1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
  • Pinch of salt
method:
1. If using a food processor: break off the florets and put them into the food processor; fix the lid and then pulse until you have a rice consistency. If using a grater: break off large florets and grate them with the large-holed side of the grater.
  2. Heat the oil in a pan over medium heat, then cook the cauliflower until softened but still al dente.
  3. Season with a little salt and serve.
tips:
Cauliflower ‘Rice’ is super simple to make. All you need is a grater or food processor and a head of cauliflower.

Top tip: You can adapt this recipe to suit a range of different flavours and dishes. Here are some suggestions:

  • Cumin Rice: Add 2 tbsp olive oil to a pan and fry whole cumin seeds. When they start to pop, add in the cauliflower rice and stir until just heated through. This goes brilliantly with my Slow Cooker Lamb Curry.
  • Roasted Rice: Roast the rice in the oven until crispy and use as a crunchy topping for avocado toast or hummus. For more flavour, try roasting the rice with cumin, cinnamon and thyme.
  • Mexican Rice: Add cumin, chilli, garlic, onion, and lime and add to my Burrito Bowls.
  • Lime and Coconut Rice: Fry 1 diced white onion and 3 minced garlic cloves in the pan, before adding the cauliflower. Once the cauliflower is cooked, add 1 can of coconut cream and the juice and zest of 1 lime. Served with a scattering of chopped fresh coriander.
tags: Lunch, Dinner, Sides, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Insulin Friendly, Egg Free, Nut Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan

title: Bacon and Egg Muffins
description: Perfect for a meal prep brekkie or a packed picnic lunch (they’re like mini bacon & egg pies!).
ingredients:
4 rashers bacon (streaky works best as it’s thinner)        
4 eggs        
Additional fillings (optional): goat’s feta, chopped chives or herbs
method:
1. Preheat oven to 200°C (390°F). Lightly grease 4 holes in a muffin tin.
2. Line each lightly greased muffin hole with bacon, cutting to cover the base. Don’t worry about making it perfect - just make sure you have a little cup to hold your egg.
3. Place in the oven for 5 minutes to make it slightly crispy.
4. Remove the tray from the oven, then gently crack an egg into each bacon cup.
5. Return to the oven and bake for 10-15 minutes, until the egg whites are firm.
6. Remove each ‘muffin’ from the tray, top with feta or herbs (if using) and serve 1-2 muffins with a side of greens and sauerkraut.
tips: Top tip: These will keep in the fridge for up to 2 days, so perfect to make ahead for a quick breakfast or lunch!
tags: Breakfast, Snacks, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Soy Free, Insulin Friendly, Nut Free

title: Salsa Verde
ingredients:
• 2 handfuls parsley leaves, de-stemmed
  • 1 handful chives, chopped
  • 240ml extra virgin olive oil
  • 45g capers
  • 3 garlic cloves, peeled
  • 4 tbsp lemon juice
  • 2 tsp Dijon mustard
  • Ground black pepper
  • ¼ small red onion, chopped
  • 1 small tin (8-10) anchovies, drained
  • 1 cooked egg yolk
method: 1. Put all ingredients into a food processor and process until smooth. Keep in a covered jar in the fridge for up to one week, or freeze and defrost when needed.
tips: (Makes 2 cups)
tags: sides, condiments, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Insulin Friendly, Nut free

title: Date-Free Powerballs
ingredients:
• 125g coconut butter (made from coconut flakes)
  • 125g cashew butter
  • 80g chia seeds, soaked in 120ml coconut milk
  • 50g coconut flakes
  • 50g cocoa
  • Desiccated coconut, for rolling the balls in
method:
1. Make the coconut butter by pulsing 125g coconut flakes and pulsing them in the food processor. 
  2. Add the cashew butter, soaked chia seeds, coconut flakes, and cocoa and process until smooth. 
  3. Take spoonfuls of the mixture and shape them into even-sized balls. Roll each of the balls in desiccated coconut. Store in the freezer and enjoy during active adventures!
tips:
I love bliss balls. In fact, I used to live on them! I thought that because they were made with natural ingredients then they had to be ‘healthy’. That was before I realised that ‘healthy’ is a relative term and no matter whether the sugar comes from dates, refined sugar, maple syrup, etc, it’s still too much for those of us who need to reverse insulin resistance. 

So I created my own balls, with no sugar or sweetener - the coconut and cashew butter balances out the bitterness of the cocoa -  which don’t taste sweet so you’re not feeding your addiction to sugar. However, like many of the other treats, these are too calorie-dense to be eating every day if your goal is to lose weight. Instead, keep them in the freezer for your active adventures.
tags: Sweets, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Insulin Friendly, nut free

title: Slow Roasted Tomatoes
ingredients:
• 30 cherry tomatoes or small vine tomatoes
  • 60ml extra virgin olive oil
  • 2 tbsp balsamic vinegar
  • Salt and pepper
method:
1. Preheat oven to 150°C (300°F).
  2. Line a baking tray with greaseproof paper and spread the tomatoes out on it. Drizzle with the oil and vinegar, and season with salt and pepper.
  3. Bake the tomatoes for 1 hour and 15 minutes or until slightly shrivelled.
  4. Serve with the juices from the pan or store in the fridge for up to 1 week.
tips: I love to make a dish of these on a Sunday evening while I’m cooking and then eat them throughout the week with some protein and a big green salad.
tags: lunch, dinner, sides,	Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Insulin Friendly, nut free

title: Roasted Turmeric Cauliflower
ingredients:
• 2 tbsp olive oil
  • 1 tbsp ground cumin
  • 1 tbsp turmeric
  • 1 tsp crushed red pepper
  • ½ tsp salt
  • 1 head cauliflower, cored and cut into florets
  • 70g pine nuts or almonds
  • 2 tbsp coriander, chopped
  • 1 tbsp mint, chopped
  • Pomegranate seeds, to garnish (optional)
method:
1. Preheat oven to 160°C (320°F). In a small bowl, combine the olive oil, cumin, turmeric, red pepper and salt. 
  2. On a large baking tray, drizzle with cauliflower with the spiced oil and toss well to thoroughly coat. Spread the cauliflower in an even layer, season with salt and bake for about 40 minutes or until browned and tender. Meanwhile, toast the pine nuts in a large dry frying pan for about 1 minute.
  3. Transfer the cauliflower to a large serving bowl. Sprinkle with the toasted pine nuts, coriander, mint, and pomegranate seeds and serve.
tips: This is one of my most-loved dishes from my favourite restaurant in southern Spain (Tarifa Eco Centre, if you’re ever in that part of the world). All of their food is incredible and seasonally produced which is something that I really like, even though it means that I can’t get this dish all year round!. I made sure to become good friends with the staff there so that I could learn how to make this and have it whenever I like.
tags: lunch, dinner, sides, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Insulin Friendly, Nut free

title: Roasted Baby Carrots
ingredients:
• 900g baby carrots washed and leafy tops removed 
  • 2½ tbsp extra virgin olive oil
  • 1½ tbsp lemon juice
  • 1 tbsp finely chopped parsley 
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • Salt and pepper
method:
1. Preheat oven to 160°C (320°F). 
  2. Lay the carrots on a baking tray, drizzle with oil, sprinkle on the garlic and season with salt and pepper.   
  3. Roast the carrots in the oven, turning occasionally, for 25-30 minutes or until tender and slightly caramelised. Serve immediately.
tips: These are a great low carb alternative to roast potatoes that you can have with your Sunday roast. Make a variation of this with baby parsnips, or a mix of carrots and parsnips.
tags: lunch, dinner, sides,	Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian, Vegan, Nut free

title: Courgette Fries
ingredients:
• 2 medium courgettes, sliced into fries
  • 2 egg whites, beaten
  • 50g almond meal
  • 2 tbsp sesame seeds, optional
  • 1 tbsp dried herbs (I like rosemary)
  • Salt and pepper
  • Coconut or extra virgin olive oil
method:
1. Preheat oven to 200°C (390°F) and lightly coat a baking tray with oil.
  2. Put the almond meal into a small bowl and combine with the sesame seeds if using.
  3. Dip the courgette fries into the egg, then roll in the almond meal. Place on the baking tray.
  4. Bake the fries for 25-30 minutes or until golden brown.
tips:
These are the most amazing low carb fries ever! Crunchy on the outside but super soft in the middle and packed with green veggie goodness!

Serve these with some pesto or lemony aioli (add some extra lemon to my 2 Minute Mayo) as an appetizer, or with steak and salad.
tags: Lunch, Dinner, Sides, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Insulin Friendly, Nut Free, Soy Free, Vegetarian

title: Braised Red Cabbage
ingredients:
• 3 tbsp ghee
  • ½ large red cabbage, shredded
  • 2 tbsp currants
  • 1 tsp salt
  • Pepper
  • 2 tbsp red wine vinegar
method:
1. Melt the ghee in a large saucepan over a medium heat. Add the cabbage, currants, salt and pepper, and stir fry for 10 minutes until the cabbage is wilted and tender.
  2. Mix in the vinegar and adjust the seasonings to taste. Serve immediately or refrigerate for up to 3 days and reheat when needed.
tips: This is a great side dish for my Devilled Sausages, Osso Bucco or any slow-cooked meal. The tanginess of the vinegar and slight sweetness of the currants create an interesting but delicious flavour.
tags: side, vegetarian, nut free, gluten free, insulin friendly

title: Scrambled Tofu
ingredients:
1 Tbsp oil
1/8 onion, finely diced (optional)
1 tsp cumin seeds or similar (optional)
150g tofu
2 eggs, beaten
Pinch of chilli flakes (optional)

For serving:
1 handful spinach
1 tomato, diced
2 Tbsp chopped coriander
1 Tbsp pumpkin seeds/ pepitas
method:
1. Heat oil in a non-stick frying pan on medium heat. Dice onion and add to pan with cumin seeds (if using) and cook for about 3 minutes, until beginning to soften.
2. Crumble tofu and add to the pan with onion. Cook for 3-4 minutes, until tofu is beginning to brown.
3. Beat eggs and add to pan, along with chilli flakes (if using). Stir to coat tofu and cook for a further 3 minutes, or until egg is cooked.
4. Serve scrambled tofu with spinach, diced tomato and coriander leaves.
tips: To make this vegan, simply omit the egg and cook scrambled tofu until tofu is cooked through.
tags: breakfast, Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Vegetarian, Insulin Friendly, nut free
